newsitem.title: USA: U.S. High Court denies ABC appeal over libel award.
newsitem.headline: U.S. High Court denies ABC appeal over libel award.

text.p: The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday rejected an appeal by ABC Inc. involving a libel award exceeding $1 million over a 1992 news broadcast stating that a company's garbage recycling machine "does not work."

News organization ABC, a unit of The Walt Disney Company broadcast a story on its "World News Tonight with Peter Jennings" on July 2, 1992 dealing with the problems facing Berrien County, Georgia after it had purchased the machine from Lundell Manufacturing Co.
The story was part of a series of reports on "Anger in America" designed to explore why people were frustrated or angry at the government.

Reporter Rebecca Chase said the county issued millions of dollars in revenue bonds to buy the machine, which was supposed to make a profit. The plant proved to be far more expensive to operate than expected and eventually was shut down.
The segment concluded by noting that taxpayers had to have their garbage hauled to another county for disposal.
Lundell sued ABC in federal court in Iowa, alleging that the statement that the recycling machine "does not work" falsely implied it was not mechanically operable.

ABC acknowledged the machine was mechanically sound, but said the county no longer used it because it could not sell the by-products -- fuel pellets and compost -- at a price sufficient to cover the machine's operating expenses.

After an eight-day trial, a jury awarded Lundell $900,000 in damages for injury to its reputation and $158,000 for lost profits. A federal judge set aside the judgment as a matter of law, but a U.S. appeals court last year reinstated the award.

ABC in its high court appeal said Lundell should have been considered a "limited purpose public figure" because it was involved in a continuing public controversy. Libel judgments are much harder to win in cases involving public figures.
ABC said it was important "to provide the press with the breathing space" under the public figure standard when a plaintiff has invited public attention and assumed the risk of media scrutiny.
But the Supreme Court turned down ABC's appeal without comment of dissent.
